items.title: [MIT Technology Review] Yann LeCunâ€™s new venture is a contrarian bet against large language models
items.content_html: Yann LeCun is a Turing Award recipient and a top AI researcher, but he has long been a contrarian figure in the tech world. He believes that the industryâ€™s current obsession with large language models is wrong-headed and will ultimately fail to solve many pressing problems.  Instead, he thinks we should be betting on world…

items.title: [Kottke.org] “Most technologies are like guns. They tend to get aggregated and captured...
items.content_html: “Most technologies are like guns. They tend to get aggregated and captured by those who already have a lot. Technology, in other words, generally exhibits preferential attachment to power.”

items.title: [Kottke.org] Water bankruptcy is a “chronic condition that develops when a place uses...
items.content_html: Water bankruptcy is a “chronic condition that develops when a place uses more water than nature can reliably replace, and when the damage to the natural assets that store and filter that water, such as aquifers and wetlands, becomes hard to reverse”.

items.content_html: Buckminster Fuller was, in many ways, a twenty-first century man: an achievement in itself, considering he was born in the nineteenth century and died in the twentieth. items.title: [Science-Based Medicine] WHO On Traditional Medicine
items.content_html:
Recently the World Health Organization published their guidelines on traditional medicine, actually referring to the category of “traditional, complementary and integrative medicine (TCIM) practices.” As has long been the case, there are some good parts to their approach, but also some concerning aspects, and at times it feels self-contradictory. The problems begin with their definition. I dislike lumping traditional, complementary, and integrative […]

The post WHO On Traditional Medicine first appeared on Science-Based Medicine.

The problems begin with their definition. I dislike lumping traditional, complementary, and integrative […]
